report_title: Big Hat Group Weekly Security Update Report
report_description: The Weekly Security Update Report is provided by Big Hat Group with the goal of making it easier to find the information System Administrators and Security Professionals need to keep their systems secure. The CVE Weekly Report is provided as a beta resource.

section_1_data.title: Chromium: CVE-2023-4368 Insufficient policy enforcement in Extensions API
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by CVE-2023-4368, an insufficient policy enforcement vulnerability in the Extensions API. This vulnerability, assigned by Chrome, is addressed by ingesting Chromium, and the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is no longer vulnerable. The underlying cause is a flaw in the Chromium Open Source Software (OSS) consumed by Microsoft Edge. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to bypass extension policy enforcement and potentially execute arbitrary code. Microsoft has provided a solution by releasing a security update for Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with the build number 116.0.1938.54. System administrators are advised to update their Microsoft Edge installations to the latest version to mitigate the risk of exploitation. For more information, refer to the Google Chrome Releases page.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability in Chromium Open Source Software (OSS) allows for insufficient policy enforcement in Extensions API.
section_1_data.fixes: The fix for this vulnerability is to update to the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based), which is no longer vulnerable. The version is 116.0.1938.54, released on 8/21/2023.

section_1_data.title: Chromium: CVE-2023-4366 Use after free in Extensions
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by a use after free vulnerability in Extensions, identified as CVE-2023-4366. This vulnerability was assigned by Chrome and is addressed by ingesting Chromium. The latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with build number 116.0.1938.54 is no longer vulnerable. The vulnerability is caused by a flaw in the Chromium Open Source Software (OSS) consumed by Microsoft Edge. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user. Microsoft has provided a solution by releasing a security update for Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with the build number 116.0.1938.54. System administrators are advised to update their Microsoft Edge installations to the latest version to mitigate the risk of exploitation. For more information, refer to the [Google Chrome Releases](https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2023) page.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability manifests as a use-after-free condition in the Extensions component of Chromium, which is used by Microsoft Edge.
section_1_data.fixes: The fix for this vulnerability is to update to the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based), which is no longer vulnerable. The version is 116.0.1938.54.

section_1_data.title: Chromium: CVE-2023-4365 Inappropriate implementation in Fullscreen
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by CVE-2023-4365, an inappropriate implementation in Fullscreen, assigned by Chrome. This vulnerability is in the Chromium Open Source Software (OSS) consumed by Microsoft Edge. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code in the context of the current user. Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) ingests Chromium, which addresses this vulnerability. The latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with build number 116.0.1938.54 is no longer vulnerable. System administrators are advised to update their Microsoft Edge installations to this version to mitigate the risk of exploitation. For more information, refer to the [Google Chrome Releases](https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2023) page.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability manifests as an inappropriate implementation in Fullscreen mode in Chromium, which is used by Microsoft Edge.
section_1_data.fixes: The fix for this vulnerability is to update to the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based), which is no longer vulnerable. The version number is 116.0.1938.54.

section_1_data.title: Chromium: CVE-2023-4364 Inappropriate implementation in Permission Prompts
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by CVE-2023-4364, an inappropriate implementation in Permission Prompts. This vulnerability was assigned by Chrome and is related to the Chromium Open Source Software (OSS) consumed by Microsoft Edge. Attackers could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code. Microsoft has addressed this vulnerability by ingesting Chromium, and the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is no longer vulnerable. System administrators are advised to update their Microsoft Edge installations to the latest version, 116.0.5845.96/.97, to mitigate the risk of exploitation. For more information, refer to the Google Chrome Releases page. The vulnerability is documented in the Security Update Guide to announce that the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is no longer vulnerable. Microsoft has provided a security update for Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with the build number 116.0.5845.96/.97. For further details, visit the Microsoft Security Response Center's page.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability manifests as an inappropriate implementation in permission prompts in Chromium, which is used by Microsoft Edge.
section_1_data.fixes: The fix for this vulnerability involves updating to the latest version of Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) which is no longer vulnerable. The version is 116.0.1938.54, released on 8/21/2023.

section_1_data.title: CVE-2023-38158 Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by an information disclosure vulnerability, identified as CVE-2023-38158, with a low severity CVSS score of 3.1/2.7. The vulnerability requires user interaction for exploitation, where the victim needs to open the vulnerable app. Successful exploitation could lead to limited information disclosure, without sensitive data exposure. The attack complexity is high, requiring additional actions by the attacker to prepare the target environment. The vulnerability is bound to the network stack, making it remotely exploitable. Microsoft has released a security update for Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) with build number 116.0.1938.54 to address this vulnerability. System administrators are advised to apply the official fix to mitigate the risk of information disclosure. For more information, refer to the Microsoft Security Response Center page for CVE-2023-38158.

section_1_data.title: CVE-2023-36787 Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability
section_1_data.summary: Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) is affected by an Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability identified as CVE-2023-36787, with a CVSS score of 8.8/7.7. The vulnerability allows an attacker to gain remote code execution privileges without requiring user interaction. It is rated as moderate severity due to the need for user interaction to exploit the vulnerability. An attacker could host a website containing a specially crafted file to exploit the vulnerability, requiring the user to click a link and open the file. The affected version of Microsoft Edge is 116.0.1938.54, based on Chromium version 116.0.5845.96/.97. Microsoft has provided a security update with build number 116.0.1938.54 to address this vulnerability. System administrators are advised to apply this update to mitigate the risk of exploitation.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability allows an attacker to exploit the system over the network, leading to unauthorized access and privileges on the affected system. The exploitation requires user interaction.
section_1_data.fixes: Microsoft has provided an official fix for this vulnerability. Users are advised to apply the security update as soon as possible to protect their systems from potential attacks.

section_1_data.title: CVE-2023-35359 Windows Kernel Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability
section_1_data.summary: CVE-2023-35359 is a Windows Kernel Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability with a base score of 7.8 and a temporal score of 6.8. The vulnerability allows an attacker to gain SYSTEM privileges by exploiting a flaw in the Windows Kernel. It has a low attack complexity and requires no user interaction, making it exploitable without any interaction from any user. The impact includes high confidentiality, integrity, and availability losses. Microsoft has provided a security update for various affected products including Windows Server 2012, 2016, 2019, 2022, Windows 10, and 11. System administrators are advised to apply the official fix to mitigate the risk of exploitation. The support lifecycle for affected software can be checked on the Microsoft Support Lifecycle page.

section_1_data.title: CVE-2023-35343 Windows Geolocation Service Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
section_1_data.summary: Windows Geolocation Service is affected by a Remote Code Execution vulnerability, assigned as CVE-2023-35343 with a CVSS score of 7.8. The vulnerability allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code locally, requiring user interaction to open a malicious input file. The attack vector is local, with low attack complexity and no privileges required. Successful exploitation results in high impact on confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Microsoft has provided a security update (e.g., 5028166, 5028185) for various Windows versions (e.g., 10, 11, Server 2019, 2022) to address this vulnerability. System administrators are advised to apply the relevant security updates to mitigate the risk of exploitation. For more information, refer to the Microsoft Security Updates page.
section_1_data.symptoms: The vulnerability can be exploited locally, either through direct access to the target system or remotely via SSH. The attacker can exploit the vulnerability by tricking a legitimate user into performing actions required for the attack.
section_1_data.fixes: Microsoft has released an official fix to address this vulnerability. Users are advised to apply the update as soon as possible to protect their systems from potential attacks.
